references: We divide knowledge following the quadrant of knowledge popularized by former US Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld, Table               1             . In this classification,         Known-Unknowns        are especially relevant. They are mainly represented by questions that do not have a definitive answer. The answers to such questions are often subjective and may vary depending on the individualâ€™s perspective or knowledge. Some questions may even be unanswerable due to a lack of information or the inherent complexity of the topic. As a result, the answers to such questions are considered to have high uncertainty levels. For example,         If the Universe started at the Big Bang, what existed before then?        . Our goal is to understand how language models deal with these kinds of uncertain questions.

In Table               2             , we show the number of questions generated per source. In the following section, we describe how the questions were generated.

references: Crowd-source          : We have used a crowd-source service to ask people to provide known-unknown questions. To achieve this, they were explained what a known-unknown question is and provided a category from Table                  3                with a set of examples. They were asked to generate a question and explain the reason why its answer is unknown.

Diving into the unknown questions, we have identified a series of reasons why a question may be unknown. We have categorized and presented them in Table                  3                , including a definition of the category and some sample questions.

To further evaluate the performance of Large Language Models in classification, we conducted a similar set of experiments on the categories classification. As in the previous experiments, models were presented with a subsample of known-unknown questions and they were expected to provide the correct category. The models were given the different categories, their definitions, and a representative example as in Table                  3                . Similarly, we performed the 1-shot experiment, few-shot, and self-ask. The used prompts can be found in Appendix                  B.3                .

Categories correspond to the list of categories given in Table                  3                . And the list of selected/unselected words correspond to the following: ["what", "how", "when", "where", "who", "which", "why", "is", "are", "will", "was", "were", "do", "did", "does", "can", "could"]

id_table_6.caption: Uncertainty Disparity Evaluation Results: It measures disparity in the uncertainty provided by the model when answering known vs unknown questions, a higher value indicates higher disparity and better performance. In parenthesis, we present the metric when the model is given if the question is known or unknown. AUD = Answer Uncertainty Disparity, explained in detail in Section.

references: In Table                     6                   , we present the general (un)certainty evaluation for the generated answers.

In addition, we also evaluate the model on this metric when the model is given if the question is known or unknown in the prompt. This experiment leads to a higher AUD value since the model benefits from having prior knowledge of the anticipated solution. The result requires further performance evaluation. The result is reported in parenthesis in Table                     6                   .
